text:
Yesterday, I had the pleasure of visiting the new Margaret Chase Smith Community School in Skowhegan. I so enjoyed reading “Antlers Forever” to the first graders and seeing their enthusiasm in the classroom.

I’m proud to have secured funding for the school’s Early Childhood Center through my role on the Senate Appropriations Committee, which will help give local students the strong educational foundation they deserve.

Today, I was delighted to be in Skowhegan to celebrate the opening of New Balance’s new factory expansion. Walking the factory floor, I saw firsthand the skill and dedication of the New Balance team and the pride they take in their work.
 
This $65 million project will create 200 new jobs, double the facility’s production capacity, and help carry forward Maine’s proud shoemaking tradition.

This morning, I attended the Blue Mass at the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception in Portland. This yearly tradition honors the courage and sacrifice of Maine’s law enforcement officers, firefighters, and first responders. Bishop James Ruggieri’s service today was a moving tribute to them.
 
I was grateful for the opportunity to join in offering prayers for those who work each day to keep our communities safe, as well as for those who have made the ultimate sacrifice in the line of duty.

I was honored to receive recognition from the Foundation to Eradicate Duchenne this week at the organization's annual “Dining Away Duchenne” event. 

Receiving this honor from the Foundation means a great deal to me, and I am grateful to Joel and Dana Wood for their commitment to this important cause. The Foundation has been a leader in funding research and supporting efforts to improve treatment for Duchenne muscular dystrophy. As Chair of the Senate Appropriations Committee, funding research for Duchenne has been among my highest priorities as this research is essential for monitoring the disease, expanding treatment options, and eventually finding a cure for all those affected.

It was wonderful to welcome dozens of Mainers to my office for another Constituent Coffee this week. We discussed numerous issues including cancer research funding, adult education, the National Science Foundation, addiction treatment, Maine’s community colleges, AmeriCorps, and the U.S. Forest Service.

Today, at a Senate HELP Committee hearing, I questioned education experts on the sharp decline in Maine students’ standardized test scores. Once consistently ranked among the top states as recently as 2011, Maine now ranks near the bottom on national standardized tests, despite the very dedicated teachers and other educators we are fortunate to have in our state.

During the hearing, the experts discussed potential causes for this decline, including the lack of incentives for high-performing teachers, policy failures, student disengagement, and broader societal factors, as well as ideas for how to address these issues.

It was a great honor to be invited to speak at the World Medical Innovation Forum this week and hear firsthand from so many experts driving innovation and patient care. 

From strengthening our health agencies and supporting rural hospitals, to ensuring access to Medicaid and advancing medical breakthroughs, our work must focus on protecting patients, empowering researchers, and maintaining America’s global leadership in health and science.

I was honored this week to receive the ANCOR Congressional Medicaid Champion Award for my efforts to protect Medicaid and Medicaid-funded services for those with intellectual and developmental disabilities.

Throughout my Senate service, protecting Medicaid has been one of my highest priorities as Medicaid is essential in supporting rural hospitals, disabled and older Americans, and many families across the State of Maine.

On this National Day of Service and Remembrance, here in Maine we especially remember Robert and Jackie Norton of Lubec, James Roux of Portland, Navy Commander Robert Schlegel of Gray, and Stephen Ward of Gorham. Each loss leaves a wound in the hearts of families and friends that can never be fully healed.

Twenty-four years after the horrific terrorist attack on our country, we remember the nearly 3,000 lives lost on September 11, 2001 – men and women at work, children and families traveling, and first responders who knowingly rushed into danger to save others.

There is no place for political violence in our nation, and no justification for such acts of pure evil.
 
Charlie Kirk dedicated his life to sharing the importance of free speech and teaching young people across our nation to talk about the issues they care about in a productive and respectful way. This assassination is a repudiation of the free and safe America he was fighting for.
 
Let us pray for Charlie's two young children and his wife Erika as they grapple with this unfathomable loss.

Our nation is facing a severe shortage of geriatric health professionals and direct service workers while the number of older Americans continues to rise rapidly. That is why, this week, I introduced the bipartisan Geriatrics Workforce Improvement Act with Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia to reauthorize the only federally funded programs specifically designed to develop a health care workforce focused on the care of older Americans.

This bill would invest nearly $50 million per year over the next five years to fund the training of more geriatric care providers and strengthen support for family caregivers. With Maine having the oldest population in the nation, this investment is especially critical for our state.

It was wonderful to be in Auburn today to help cut the ribbon on the brand-new Police Activities League Center.

The motto of the Auburn Police Activities League is, “It is better to build youth than to mend adults,” and since it was established in 2013, the Auburn PAL Center has provided boys and girls with a safe and welcoming environment in which to play and learn after school. The children and teens also receive mentoring, nutritious food, warm clothes, and needed school supplies, while building meaningful relationships with the law enforcement officers who protect them and their families. 

That is why, through my role on the Senate Appropriations Committee, I worked hard to secure $3 million in federal funding to support this important project for the community.
https://t.co/lUW2VwNW9c

Bill Diamond was a dedicated public servant and leader, an incredibly compassionate and kind person, and a wonderful friend. He was a tremendous advocate for the safety and well-being of Maine’s children through his many years as an educator and legislator but especially as the founder of Walk a Mile in Their Shoes. I am deeply saddened to learn of his passing and send my heartfelt condolences to his wife Jane.

While Labor Day marks the end of summer for many and an opportunity to get together with family and friends, let us not forget those who are working hard on this holiday: our healthcare providers and others keeping our hospitals open, our hospitality workers staffing our restaurants and hotels, our public safety officials keeping us safe, the employees in our grocery stores and those responsible for transporting vacationers, among many others. We salute all who work hard on this holiday and throughout the year.

The staff and volunteers at the Bath Area Food Bank work tirelessly to provide hot meals and groceries to individuals and families in need throughout the greater Bath area. I am thankful to have had the opportunity to see their operations firsthand and to express my appreciation to the many people who devote their time to making such a meaningful difference in the lives of hundreds of Mainers.

Today, I had the pleasure of speaking at the Maine Sheriffs' Association breakfast at the invitation of York County Sheriff Bill King Jr. 

People throughout Maine appreciate the courageous and skilled men and women of our county sheriff departments. Maine is regularly ranked as among the safest states in the nation, a distinction made possible by their effective, professional, and compassionate law enforcement and corrections services. 

That is why, as Chair of the Senate Appropriations Committee, I am working every day to ensure that Maine's law enforcement officers are able to protect themselves and our communities by providing them with the facilities and equipment they need to keep Mainers safe.

For 90 years, Social Security has been one of the most effective lifesaving programs in our nation’s history. As we recognize this important milestone, it is only fitting that this program was strengthened earlier this year with the signing of the Social Security Fairness Act, a bipartisan bill I authored to restore the earned benefits that had been unfairly withheld from teachers, firefighters, police officers, and other public servants and their spouses. We remain steadfast in our commitment to ensuring that this program continues to meet the needs of Americans now and in the decades to come.

It was wonderful to be at the Coast Guard Station in Eastport today to celebrate National Coast Guard Day, which also marks the service branch’s 235th birthday. I was grateful for the chance to meet and thank the Coast Guardsmen serving in Eastern Maine and to hear more about their work protecting our waters and supporting coastal communities.

Last night, for the first time since 2018, the Senate passed annual appropriations bills ahead of the August recess. The three bills—covering Military Construction and Veterans Affairs; Agriculture, FDA, and Rural Development; and the Legislative Branch annual appropriations—each passed with overwhelming bipartisan support.

These bills include significant investments for projects across the State of Maine.

At Portsmouth Naval Shipyard, nearly $450 million would support power reliability and water resilience upgrades, along with continued expansion of Multi-Mission Dry Dock #1.

At my request, Congressionally Directed Spending is included for new fire and rescue stations in Belgrade, Marshfield, St. Agatha, St. Albans, Thomaston, and Swan’s Island.

In addition, $10 million is provided for the PFAS Center of Excellence at the University of Maine to advance research and develop solutions to address PFAS contamination in Maine’s food and water systems.

I am pleased that, with the passage of these three bills, the Senate is returning to regular order and exercising its constitutional responsibility for the power of the purse. I look forward to continuing the bipartisan cooperation we demonstrated last night as we work to pass the remaining appropriations bills.

Tonight, Secretary of the Navy John Phelan called me to notify me that the Navy has awarded Bath Iron Works the contract to build the next DDG-51 Arleigh Burke-class destroyer.

This award is a testament to the highly skilled and hard-working men and women of BIW and once again shows that Bath Built is Best Built.

This new ship, the DDG-148, will be named after Corporal Kyle Carpenter, the youngest living Medal of Honor recipient, an American hero who risked his life shielding a fellow Marine from a grenade blast in Afghanistan in 2010.

Happy National Intern Day to the two classes of interns who’ve helped support my staff in Washington this summer. It’s been wonderful having you all. Thank you for your energy, professionalism, and your service to the people of Maine.

Top (L to R): Nelson Dorsey III, Katie Arquit, Jason Warren

Bottom (Clockwise from top left): Aston Black, James Burke (Senate Page), Charles Hubbard, Charles Jagger, Renee Bergeon

The Senate Health Committee today unanimously advanced my bipartisan bill to reauthorize the Kay Hagan Tick Act, which I first authored in 2019 with Senator Tina Smith. This legislation would continue our ongoing federal response to Lyme and other tick-borne diseases, and honors our late colleague Senator Kay Hagan, who tragically passed away from complications of the Powassan virus, a rare but serious tick-borne illness.

Maine reported a record 3,218 cases of Lyme disease last year—more than double the number from just five years ago. With cases of tick-borne illnesses increasing at such an alarming rate, reauthorizing this law is critical to continuing our ongoing research, prevention, and public health efforts. I now look forward to working with my colleagues to pass this reauthorization on the Senate floor.

Today, at a hearing of the Senate Judiciary Committee, I introduced Joshua Dunlap of Scarborough, who has been nominated to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. He came to Washington for his hearing with several members of his family, including his parents, wife, and children.

Josh grew up in Vassalboro, and is currently a partner in the litigation group of Pierce Atwood LLP, in Portland, where he co-chairs the firm’s Appellate & Amici division. He has practiced at Pierce Atwood for over fifteen years, handling substantial civil litigation matters in both appellate and trial courts. He also chairs the Maine Appellate Rules Committee, to which he was appointed by the Maine Supreme Judicial Court. Prior to his work at Pierce Atwood, Josh clerked for the Honorable Paul J. Kelly, Jr., of the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. He graduated first in his class from Notre Dame Law School.

He did an excellent job answering questions during his hearing today, and I am confident that, if confirmed, Josh will serve Maine and the nation extraordinarily well in this critical role.

Earlier this month, Petty Officer Scott Ruskan, a rescue diver for the U.S. Coast Guard, saved more than 160 people from Camp Mystic during the devastating floods that swept through Texas. It was truly an honor to meet this brave 26-year-old, who had just recently completed rescue swimming school before the floods. Our entire nation thanks this hero and everyone involved in the rescue efforts and ongoing recovery for their courage, service, and tireless work in the face of such danger and destruction.

I am glad my colleagues and I were able to work together to get these funds released so our schools and educators can prepare for the upcoming academic year with certainty and Maine students have the resources they need to succeed.
https://t.co/XuoWK8MABk

It’s not every day that I have the opportunity to meet with another Susan Margaret Collins. That made my conversation with Boston Federal Reserve Bank President Dr. Susan M. Collins all the more enjoyable as we discussed monetary policy and the economic outlook for New England and the nation.

This week, Senator Tina Smith and I introduced a bill to reauthorize our Kay Hagan Tick Act so that we can continue to support important research, diagnostics, prevention, and treatment of tick-borne diseases by providing targeted funding for state health departments and regional Centers of Excellence.

Earlier this year, I spoke at the Center for Lyme Action Congressional Series about the progress we have made thanks to Kay Hagan Tick Act, including the first-ever clinical trial for a Lyme disease vaccine for humans, which is underway right now at the MaineHealth Institute for Research. With Lyme disease cases hitting a record high of more than 3,000 last year in the State of Maine, this reauthorization is urgently needed.

Today, more than 170 delegates from all 50 states and five countries were in Washington for the 2025 Breakthrough Type 1 Diabetes Children’s Congress. I was proud to chair a Senate Appropriations Committee hearing to welcome the delegates and focus on the importance of federal investment in Type 1 diabetes research.

Senator Jeanne Shaheen and I — the founding co-chairs of the bipartisan Senate Diabetes Caucus — introduced legislation this week to reauthorize the Special Diabetes Program, a federal initiative that provides $160 million annually for Type 1 diabetes research and prevention. Thanks to this program and the tireless advocacy of @BreakthroughT1D and its Children’s Congress Delegates, we are seeing life changing breakthroughs in the fight against this terrible disease. Some of these developments include the now widely used continuous glucose monitors, the first FDA-approved artificial pancreas, and a groundbreaking clinical trial in which 10 of the 12 participants no longer need insulin to manage their diabetes because of a stem cell-based therapy. Since the founding of the Senate Diabetes Caucus in 1997, federal funding for diabetes research has increased from $319 million to more than $2.3 billion annually.

I want to thank our outstanding witnesses for today’s hearing: Ruby Whitmore of Old Town, Maine, Rachel White of North Hampton, New Hampshire, Katie Bone of Bernalillo, New Mexico, and Dr. Griffin Rodgers, Director of the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK). Their passionate testimony highlighted both the daily realities of living with type 1 diabetes and the vital role of continued federal research through agencies like the NIDDK.

Finding a cure for Type 1 diabetes remains our ultimate goal and has been one of my highest priorities since the very beginning of my Senate service. With continued advocacy, bipartisan support, and strong federal investment, I am confident that day will come.

It was great to celebrate the 4th of July with so many Mainers at the Burlington/Lowell Parade. I enjoyed walking with my good friend Representative McIntyre and catching up with other local legislators. 

As we come together with family and friends to enjoy parades, fireworks, and festivities, let us also take pause to honor the legacy of those who came before us by continuing to work toward a more perfect union for future generations.
Happy 4th of July! Each Independence Day, we celebrate the birth of our nation, the enduring spirit of freedom, and the generations who have defended it since. Wishing you a safe and joyful holiday.

I am pleased that the bill contains a special fund that I proposed to provide some assistance to our rural hospitals, but it is not sufficient to offset the other changes in the Medicaid system. 

While I continue to support the tax relief I voted for in 2017, I could not support these Medicaid changes and other issues.

This bill has additional problems. The tax credits that energy entrepreneurs have relied on should have been gradually phased out so as not to waste the work that has already been put into these innovative new projects and prevent them from being completed. The bill should have also retained incentives for Maine families who choose to install heat pumps and residential solar panels.

Certainly, there are improvements that should be made to the Medicaid system. For example, I support work requirements for able-bodied adults who are not raising young children, who are not caregivers, or attending school. However, a dramatic reduction in future Medicaid funding, an estimated $5.9 billion in Maine over the next 10 years, could threaten not only Mainers’ access to health care, but also the very existence of several of our state’s rural hospitals.

The Medicaid program has been an important health care safety net for nearly 60 years that has helped people in difficult financial circumstances, including people with disabilities, children, seniors, and low-income families. Approximately 400,000 Mainers – nearly a third of the state's population – depend on this program.

I strongly support extending the tax relief for families and small businesses. My vote against this bill stems primarily from the harmful impact it will have on Medicaid, affecting low-income families and rural health care providers like our hospitals and nursing homes.

Important research into Lyme disease is taking place in Maine that could lead to the first vaccine for humans. To make certain that this research can reach its conclusion, I asked Dr. Susan Monarez, the nominee for CDC Director, if she would commit to allowing the ongoing clinical trial at MaineHealth Institute for Research to proceed without interruption.

Maine recorded a record 3,035 cases of Lyme disease last year. This research is important, and a vaccine would mark a significant win in the fight against tick-borne diseases. As Chair of the Senate Appropriations Committee and a member of the HELP Committee, I will continue to advocate for strong federal support for research into these growing public health threats.

Statement on the Iran War Powers Resolution: 

Since the despicable attacks on October 7, 2023, Iran has continued to use proxies and empowered terrorist groups to attack American servicemembers and our ally Israel. This week, Iran threatened to attack Americans on our own soil and around the world.

I supported the President’s targeted strike on Iran’s pursuit of nuclear capabilities because a nuclear-armed Iran would pose an unacceptable threat to America and our allies. I also applaud the current ceasefire. Given this backdrop, it is the wrong time to consider this resolution and to risk inadvertently sending a message to Iran that the President cannot swiftly defend Americans at home and abroad.

There has always been a Constitutional tension between Article I vesting in Congress the power to declare war and Article II designating the President as Commander-in-Chief. I continue to believe that Congress has an important responsibility to authorize the sustained use of military force. That is not the situation we are facing now. The President has the authority to defend our nation and our troops around the world against the threat of attack.
It’s always a pleasure to hear directly from Mainers. I’m thankful to those who joined this week’s Constituent Coffee to share their perspectives. https://t.co/HgdWgms1ld

Yesterday, I chaired an Appropriations Committee hearing to review the Administration’s proposed rescissions package. I questioned OMB Director Russ Vought about the potential effects of the proposed rescissions on life-saving programs, including HIV/AIDS prevention efforts and maternal and child health programs—such as those that provide therapeutic food supplements and prenatal vitamins.

These initiatives have saved tens of millions of lives around the world and are essential to the United States’ humanitarian leadership and global influence.

We also discussed the potential impacts of the rescissions package on the local public television and radio stations that provide emergency communications in rural Maine and across the country.

Maine has produced Olympic medalists, collegiate national champions, and standout professional athletes, but we've never seen a Mainer drafted into a major sports league with this kind of global spotlight. Cooper Flagg’s rise from the gymnasium at Nokomis Regional High School to the national stage is truly extraordinary. And even though he won’t be playing for the Celtics, all of Maine will be rooting for his continued success.

Photo: Cindy Russell

It was wonderful speaking with the bright and talented students attending the Cohen Institute High School Summer Leadership Program at the University of Maine this past weekend. The curiosity and enthusiasm of young Mainers always gives me great hope for the future. https://t.co/WUzqeuLmrU

The precision strike that the President ordered was a necessary response to Iran’s aggressive pursuit of nuclear weapons. This limited and decisive action is far preferable to the much broader conflict that would be all but inevitable if Iran were to obtain nuclear weapons.

A nuclear-armed Iran poses an existential threat to our ally Israel. Ultimately, as Iran continues to develop the capacity of its ballistic missiles, our country is also in danger.
I appreciated the opportunity to hear from Mainers during this week’s Constituent Coffee. Thank you to all who attended. https://t.co/4Y2mvdTzjs

The attacks on public officials and their families in Minnesota are tragic and horrifying. Instances of political violence and threats are becoming far too common in our country. We must stand united in support of the victims’ families, survivors, and local law enforcement as they seek the perpetrator of these heinous crimes.

I was proud to join community members and elected officials today in Eastport to celebrate the completion of major improvements at Eastport Municipal Airport, including a new terminal and runway. Dozens of local residents were in attendance for the inaugural Airport Community Day to recognize these upgrades and to highlight the airport’s vital role in connecting Downeast Maine to the rest of the world.

These upgrades were made possible by nearly $7 million in federal funding awarded to the City of Eastport in 2019 and 2024. That funding came through supplemental Airport Improvement Program and Airport Terminal Program investments I championed through my work on the Senate Appropriations Committee and as one of the ten senators who negotiated the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law, which ensures smaller airports like Eastport Municipal Airport receive the support they need.

Today, we celebrate the 250th birthday of the United States Army. For two and a half centuries, the Army has defended our nation, responded in times of crisis, and upheld the cause of freedom.

Its legacy is defined not only by battlefield victories, but by the strength, discipline, and courage of the men and women who have proudly worn the uniform.

One of them was my father, Donald Collins, who served as an infantry sergeant in World War II. He was wounded twice and earned two Purple Hearts and a Bronze Star for his service during the Battle of the Bulge. I recently traveled with a bipartisan Senate delegation to Belgium and Luxembourg to honor those who fought in that pivotal campaign 80 years ago, and to reflect on the extraordinary sacrifices made by our Greatest Generation.

From the Revolutionary War to the Civil War, World War I, World War II, and all other conflicts where the U.S. Army has been called upon, soldiers have stood ready to serve, and the people of our nation are forever grateful.
I’m grateful to all the Mainers who joined me for another Constituent Coffee this week. https://t.co/sOwdtdDOXd

Iran has greatly expanded its uranium enrichment with the goal of producing nuclear weapons that pose an existential threat to Israel. 

Our country too is at risk as Iran continues its development not only of fissile material but also of ballistic missiles. 

I hope the Israeli operation to eliminate Iran’s nuclear capability is successful.

At an Appropriations hearing to review the National Institutes of Health’s (NIH) budget, I pressed the NIH Director on the Administration’s proposal to cut funding for biomedical research. These cuts would result in a nearly 40% reduction in funding for the National Institute on Aging, which supports most Alzheimer’s research.

As progress is finally being made with early detection tools and treatments that can slow Alzheimer’s disease, now is not the time to slash funding. Through my role as Chair of the Senate Appropriations Committee, I will continue to fight for funding to support lifesaving biomedical research.

Thank you to Mary Dysart Hartt and her husband Mike for introducing me at the event. Mary and Mike live in Hampden, and Mary has been a tireless advocate on behalf of Maine's Alzheimer's patients, like Mike, and their caregivers.
https://t.co/GWWK5OqwSe

It was an honor to speak to the more than 1,000 Alzheimer's advocates from Maine and across the country at the #alzforum. The work being done by the @alzassociation is making a real difference in the fight against this disease.

81 years ago today, Allied forces launched the D-Day invasion, storming the beaches of Normandy with extraordinary courage and determination.

Their sacrifice helped turn the tide of World War II and preserve freedom and democracy in Europe.

We owe an enduring debt to the Greatest Generation—both those who fought on the front lines and those who supported the war effort at home. Their service must never be forgotten.

Maine’s lobster industry is the backbone of many of our coastal communities and a critical part of our state’s economy.

Regulations proposed by the Biden Administration threatened the very existence of the lobster industry in our state. The entire Maine Delegation worked together to block them, and a federal court later found that the Administration’s proposals were based on models that were "very likely wrong,” calling the regulations "arbitrary and capricious."

During an Appropriations hearing this week, I pressed the Secretary of Commerce to ensure that all future regulation of this industry is grounded in rigorous, evidence-based science. I appreciated his strong endorsement of the Maine lobster industry as “an American treasure,” as well as his commitment that the current Administration will not undermine the fishery with burdensome regulations rooted in flawed science.

The Administration’s proposal to eliminate TRIO programs like Upward Bound would take away educational opportunities from the students who need them most. These programs help low-income and first-generation students overcome barriers to higher education. In fact, three of my own staff members are TRIO alumni. They’ve told me that without the support and guidance that TRIO programs provided them, they likely would not have pursued college.

That’s why I pressed the Secretary of Education to explain this proposal. While I appreciate her acknowledgment of TRIO’s demonstrated success, the Administration’s concerns about lack of oversight do not warrant the elimination of programs that work. As I told her, if there are problems with how TRIO is structured, then let’s fix them, not abandon these programs entirely.

As Chair of the Senate Appropriations Committee and Co-Chair of the congressional TRIO Caucus, I will continue fighting to preserve and strengthen these life-changing education programs.

Today, I was in Clinton to meet with local first responders and review plans for the new fire station I am supporting with $2 million in Congressionally Directed Spending. Touring the current fire station gave me a clear picture of the challenges facing Clinton firefighters and EMTs to swiftly respond to emergency situations. I am glad I could provide Clinton’s first responders and residents with this funding for an upgraded facility, and I appreciate Deputy Fire Chief Travis Leary for sharing these plans with me.

It was a great honor yesterday to participate in the Town of Lincoln’s Memorial Day observance at the park recognizing those who served our country, including Medal of Honor recipient Master Sergeant Gary Gordon. https://t.co/lBOtmgy1L2

On Memorial Day, we take pause and reflect on our fallen American heroes and their families to honor their selfless service to our nation. Let us never forget the generations of men and women who have made the ultimate sacrifice for our freedom.

We are the land of the free, because of the brave.

The Department of Labor’s decision to halt enrollment at Maine’s Loring and Penobscot Job Corps Centers is deeply misguided and will do damage to hundreds of young people. These programs serve nearly 500 Mainers a year and are pillars of support for some of our state’s most vulnerable teens. Loring alone employs 129 people, making it also one of the largest employers in rural northern Maine.

To show what’s at stake, today, I shared with the Secretary of Labor the story of Adais Viruet-Torres. When I first met Adais in 2008, she was a Job Corps student at Loring, having escaped a dangerous and unstable life in Connecticut and New York. With training and support from the Loring Job Corps Center, she turned her life around, later earning her nursing degree with honors from Husson in 2019, and continuing on to become a nurse practitioner.

Job Corps works, and it offers so many at-risk young people a real chance at a better life. Eliminating it would rob tens of thousands of students nationwide of the opportunity to gain skills, pursue higher education, join the workforce, and build towards a future they can be proud of—just like Adais.

I am horrified by last night’s terrorist attack at the Jewish Museum and the senseless murder of two young people.

Yaron Lischinsky and Sarah Milgrim were attending an event centered around humanitarian diplomacy in the Middle East, including in Gaza—tragically, unfathomably, it cost them their lives as they were about to be engaged.

Relentless, deliberate antisemitic and anti-Israel hate leads to violence and tragedy. It cannot be tolerated.

My heart breaks for those who love Yaron and Sarah, for their grieving colleagues at the Israeli Embassy in Washington, and for all who bear the weight of working to end the horrors inflicted by Hamas.
I am saddened to hear of President Biden’s cancer diagnosis and am wishing him and his family well as he begins treatment.

Today, I had the honor of joining the Rumford community to dedicate the town’s new fire station in memory of Peter Chase, a beloved Deputy Fire Chief and Town Selectman who passed away in 2022. The ceremony was especially moving as it took place on what would have been Peter's 72nd birthday. It was wonderful to be joined at the ceremony by members of his family, including his wife Rhonda and son Bob, who continues his father’s legacy as Chief of the Auburn Fire Department.

I was proud to secure $1 million in Congressionally Directed Spending through my role on the Senate Appropriations Committee to help build this modern facility, which replaces the old station that was built in 1923.

The new station is a fitting tribute to Peter’s lifelong public service and to the firefighters who protect this community every day.

National Police Week serves as an important reminder of the sacrifices our law enforcement officers make every single day to protect our communities. We owe a tremendous debt of gratitude to the brave men and women who put everything on the line to keep us safe. https://t.co/8VYLjsF0O3

It was a great pleasure to join local, county, and state officials in Presque Isle to break ground on a new passenger terminal at Presque Isle International Airport.

I was proud to secure $20.4 million for this project through my role on the Senate Appropriations Committee, which will replace the 70-year-old terminal with a modern, FAA and ADA compliant facility that can better serve Northern Maine and support future growth in the region. With the new terminal, PQI will be well positioned to attract more travelers, expand service, and support economic development across Aroostook County.

Today, Northern Maine Community College held its 60th Commencement ceremony. I had the honor of delivering the keynote address to more than 200 graduates, along with their families and the dedicated NMCC faculty gathered at the Presque Isle Forum.

From future nurses and mechanics to wind technicians, early childhood educators, and more, NMCC graduates are well prepared to strengthen Maine’s workforce in critical roles. Congratulations to the NMCC Class of 2025 on this important milestone!

Blessings to Pope Leo XIV, our first American Pope, on his selection to serve as the Bishop of Rome. May he receive guidance from Jesus Christ our Lord and inspire the global community of Catholics and all people by sharing the message of God’s unconditional love.

Yesterday, at a Senate Appropriations Agriculture Subcommittee hearing, I questioned Secretary Brooke Rollins on the delayed release of USDA grant funding awarded to farmers in the previous fiscal year.

Growing up in Aroostook County and having worked my first job on a potato farm, I know how much our farmers rely on these funds to plan for the season. When the timeline for receiving funding is uncertain, farmers lack the necessary clarity to make planting decisions and equipment purchases.

Delays can lead to low harvest yields, lost income, a diminished food supply, and more family farms shutting down. Maine has already lost 600 farms in the past decade. We cannot afford to lose more.

Over the past two weeks, my staff and I have welcomed nearly 100 Mainers to my office for Constituent Coffee. I’m grateful to everyone who took the time to meet with me, and I look forward to continuing these conversations. https://t.co/ZjI0zVFG3Y

Today’s announcement from the University of Maine that it has received full funding for Maine Sea Grant is terrific news for the fishermen, lobstermen, hospitality workers, and so many others in Maine that rely on a productive and growing coastal economy.

After a February announcement from the Department of Commerce that the program was being defunded, I contacted Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick and the Trump administration to explain all that is at stake for Maine’s coastal communities with the loss of Sea Grant funding. After several productive conversations, Secretary Lutnick directed NOAA to renegotiate the terms and conditions of the work to be performed by Maine Sea Grant to ensure that it focuses on advancing Maine’s coastal economies, working waterfronts, and sustainable fisheries, and, this week, they received their funding.

I am thrilled that Maine Sea Grant has received its full funding so that the important work they do to conduct research, support a robust pipeline of skilled labor, and enrich our state’s economy can continue unimpeded. Maine Sea Grant has more than 700 established partnerships with businesses, researchers, community organizations, and local and county governments, and their work contributed to $23.5 million in documented economic benefits in 2023 alone. For every $1 of funding for Maine Sea Grant, our state has seen a $15 return—this is a valuable investment into Maine’s bright future.

Click here to read the announcement from the University of Maine: https://t.co/dcrLRPIXX5

It was deeply moving today to welcome Abigail Mor Edan to the Capitol for Members of Congress to meet this incredibly brave young girl. 
 
On October 7th, 2023, Hamas terrorists forced their way into Abigail’s family home in Israel. Her parents, Roy and Smadar, were shot and killed while attempting to shield the then 3-year-old Abigail from Hamas, while her older siblings Michael and Amalia hid silently in a closet for 14 hours before being rescued. Abigail was taken hostage by the terrorists, who held her in captivity for 51 days. Abigail’s 4th birthday occurred as she was still being held hostage.
 
I learned of Abigail’s story from her aunt, Liz Hirsh Naftali, soon after the October 7th attacks. Liz gave me Abigail’s picture and asked me to share her story. On a Senate delegation trip to Israel, I held up that picture during an international news conference to show the world that Hamas had taken innocent hostages, like this 3-year-old girl who had just witnessed the murder of both her parents. Abigail’s photo accompanied me at events throughout her captivity as a reminder of the families torn apart by the attacks and the urgent need to bring all the hostages home.
 
Today’s event was an occasion to celebrate the unbelievable strength and resilience of this now 5-year-old girl whose life has already been marked by unimaginable tragedy, and yet who continues to inspire with her ceaseless courage and spirit.
 
It was also a solemn reminder of the hostages that still remain in captivity today, and the work that must continue to bring those remaining hostages home to their families.

Today, I Chaired the first full committee hearing of the Senate Appropriations Committee in the 119th Congress. The topic of our hearing, “Biomedical Research: Keeping America’s Edge in Innovation,” speaks to the high priority that our committee places on biomedical research. There is no investment that pays greater dividends to American families than our investment in this research, which can lead to life-saving and life-enhancing discoveries.

Among our witnesses was Dr. Hermann Haller, the President of @MDIBL, who spoke about how the proposed NIH cap on indirect costs for federally funded research would affect the important biomedical research occurring in Maine and at institutions across the country.

The conflict between how the State of Maine and the Administration interpret Title IX needs to be resolved.  I agree with the federal government’s position that biological males should not compete in girls and women’s athletics. Policies to the contrary violate the original intent behind Title IX.

People who are transgender deserve to be treated with respect and dignity.  But that does not change the fact that Title IX mandated equal access to athletic resources and facilities on the basis of sex – not on the basis of gender identity. Safe and fair athletic competition has been one of the keys to the success of Title IX.

While I will continue to advocate strongly for federal funding for Maine,  I disagree with the state’s position and instead support the original intent behind Title IX.

In Maine and across the country, many dedicated religious workers have had to leave the communities they serve because of visa backlogs. The Religious Workforce Protection Act I introduced with Senators Tim Kaine and Jim Risch would allow lawfully present religious workers with R-1 visas to remain in the U.S. while awaiting a decision from the Department of Homeland Security on their EB-4 permanent visa applications.

If this issue is not addressed, religious organizations in Maine and throughout the U.S. will continue to lose beloved pastors, priests, rabbis, and other religious workers who lead and support their congregations and communities.

Yesterday, I spoke from the Senate floor in support of the effort to overturn the emergency declaration for the northern border that has been used to impose tariffs on goods imported from Canada.

While I share the President’s goal of stemming the tide of dangerous fentanyl that flows into the United States, the fact is, the vast majority of the fentanyl in America comes from the southern border. In fiscal year 2024, less than 1% of fentanyl seizures occurred at our northern border, and the Canadians are working cooperatively with our government to stop that trafficking. Unlike Mexico and China, Canada is not complicit in this crisis.

The State of Maine’s economy is deeply integrated with Canada, our most important trading partner. The price hikes that will affect Mainers—from the grocery store, to filling their gas and heating oil tanks—will be so harmful. And as price hikes always do, they will hurt those the most who can afford them the least.

I am pleased that the Trump Administration is pausing the tariffs on Canada to evaluate the economic impact on both our nations. 

In my many conversations with Administration officials over the weekend, I sought to make them aware of the potential costs of these tariffs. From home heating oil, gasoline, and petroleum products, to Maine’s paper mills, forest products businesses, and agricultural producers, the proposed tariffs on Canada would be detrimental to Maine families and our local economies. 

As the Administration assesses next steps, I’ll work to ensure Mainers have a seat at the table.

The Maine economy is integrated with Canada, our most important trading partner. Certain tariffs will impose a significant burden on many families, manufacturers, the forest products industry, small businesses, lobstermen, and agricultural producers.

For example, 95 percent of the heating oil used by most Mainers to heat their homes comes from refineries in Canada. The Air National Guard Base in Bangor depends completely on jet fuel and diesel from Canada. From fisheries to potato farmers to paper mills, these tariffs will have a significant impact on Maine’s economy and risk increasing costs for our residents.

I am working with the Trump Administration to help its officials better understand the potential ramifications of certain tariffs on Maine and to find out more about their implementation, scope, duration, and other important information, including any exemptions they may make for northern border states, certain industries, agricultural producers, and others who rely on trade with Canada.

80 years ago today, the Battle of the Bulge ended with Allied victory, marking a crucial turning point in World War II.

Last month, on the anniversary of when this battle began, I traveled with a bipartisan delegation to ceremonies in Belgium and Luxembourg to honor the brave Allied soldiers who fought in this historic battle—including my own father, who was wounded twice, earning two Purple Hearts and a Bronze Star.

It’s easy to see why we call these brave servicemembers our greatest generation.

Our nation is currently facing serious threats on multiple fronts, including at our northern and southern borders. Mexican drug cartels, especially, are using the chaos at the southern border to facilitate their drug and human trafficking operations and to flood our nation with fentanyl and other illegal drugs. 

As Governor of South Dakota, Kristi Noem understands that what happens at the southern border has repercussions for communities all over the United States, including here in Maine. After careful consideration, I have decided to vote against Pete Hegseth’s nomination for Secretary of Defense. While I appreciate his courageous military service and his ongoing commitment to our servicemembers and their families, I am concerned that he does not have the experience and perspective necessary to succeed in the job.

Our military is under tremendous pressure right now. Active conflicts in the Middle East and Europe combined with escalating threats in the Pacific, all against a backdrop of severe financial challenges and four years of ineffective leadership by the Biden Administration, make this an especially critical time for those who lead our military. The next Secretary of Defense will be responsible for managing a massive bureaucracy that includes nearly three million employees and a budget of nearly $850 billion. In addition, our next Secretary faces long-standing procurement and supply issues that continued to worsen under the Biden Administration.

In sum, the Secretary is going to be facing a number of incredibly complex problems that are going to require highly skilled management ability. I am concerned that Mr. Hegseth does not have the management experience and background that he will need in order to tackle these difficulties. His limited managerial experience involved running two small non-profit organizations that had decidedly mixed results.

I am also concerned about multiple statements, including some in the months just before he was nominated, that Mr. Hegseth has made about women serving in the military. He and I had a candid conversation in December about his past statements and apparently evolving views. I am not convinced that his position on women serving in combat roles has changed.

Women comprise nearly 18 percent of our active-duty military. They continue to make critical and valuable contributions to our national defense. I have long advocated that women who wish to serve in and can meet the rigorous standards of combat roles should be able to do so. And numerous women have proved that they can accomplish this difficult feat.

Currently, thousands of women are serving in combat roles and many others serve in non-combat functions.  Their service is essential to the success of our military.

Mr. Hegseth also appears to lack a sufficient appreciation for some of the policies that the military is required to follow because they are codified in the laws of the United States of America. While I understand his points on the importance of up-to-date and workable rules of engagement, our prohibitions against torture come from American laws and treaties ratified by the United States, including the Geneva Conventions.

Therefore, I will vote against the nomination.

Thank you @APWUnational for your years of advocacy on this issue. It was wonderful to see APWU President Mark Dimondstein representing our nation’s postal workers at the White House as the Social Security Fairness Act was signed into law!
This is a win for fairness and for those who have dedicated their lives to serving their communities.

I have fought for this change since 2003, when I held the first-ever Senate hearing on repealing the WEP and  GPO, and I am proud that this law will ensure public service no longer comes at the expense of the retirement benefits earned by an individual or their spouse.

This law repeals the unfair Windfall Elimination Provision (WEP) and Government Pension Offset (GPO), ensuring that millions of teachers and other school employees, first responders, and other public servants will receive the Social Security benefits they or their spouse earned.

Today, I was honored to be in attendance for the signing of the Social Security Fairness Act into law, a bill I authored with Senator Sherrod Brown. 

I am so pleased that more than 25,000 Mainers will benefit from this new law. [1/4] https://t.co/a7sX1VnK5F
https://t.co/jpmQ7EtQok

This bill will ensure that millions of teachers, firefighters, law enforcement officers, and other public servants – including more than 25,000 Mainers – will finally receive the full Social Security benefits they have earned through years of work.
